canonical_explanation.text: Light is a form of energy that enables us to see objects. Objects that emit their own light are called luminous objects, while objects that do not emit light are called non-luminous objects. Materials can be classified as transparent, translucent, or opaque based on how much light passes through them. When an opaque object is placed in the path of light, a shadow is formed on the opposite side. A plane mirror reflects light and forms an image that is erect, of the same size, and laterally inverted.
rules: Light travels in a straight line (rectilinear propagation of light).
Luminous objects produce their own light (e.g., Sun, candle, electric bulb).
Non-luminous objects do not produce their own light (e.g., Moon, table, book).
Transparent objects allow all light to pass through (e.g., clear glass, water).
Translucent objects allow only some light to pass through (e.g., frosted glass, oiled paper).
Opaque objects do not allow any light to pass through (e.g., wood, metal, cardboard).
A shadow is formed when an opaque object blocks the path of light.
Three things needed for shadow formation: a light source, an opaque object, and a screen.
Shadows are always dark regardless of the colour of the object.
An image in a plane mirror is erect, same size as the object, and laterally inverted.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a luminous object?
questions.explanation_correct: The Sun is a luminous object because it produces its own light. It is a star that emits light and heat due to nuclear reactions occurring inside it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Moon reflects sunlight but does not produce its own light — it is non-luminous. A mirror reflects light but does not produce it. A diamond sparkles by reflecting and refracting light but does not produce its own light. Only the Sun produces its own light.

questions.question_text: The Moon is a non-luminous object because it:

options.text: Does not produce its own light but reflects sunlight

questions.explanation_correct: The Moon is non-luminous because it does not produce its own light. We can see the Moon because it reflects the light that falls on it from the Sun.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Moon does not produce its own light (A is wrong), does not absorb all light (C is wrong — if it did, we could not see it), and distance from Earth (D) is not the reason. It is non-luminous because it only reflects sunlight.

questions.question_text: A burning candle is a luminous object.
questions.explanation_correct: A burning candle produces its own light from the flame. Any object that emits its own light is called a luminous object, so a burning candle is indeed luminous.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. A burning candle has a flame that emits light, making it a luminous object.

questions.question_text: An object through which we can see clearly is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Transparent objects allow all or most light to pass through them, so we can see objects clearly through them. Examples include clear glass and clean water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Opaque objects do not allow any light through. Translucent objects allow only some light through, so objects appear blurred. Luminous refers to objects that emit their own light. Transparent is the correct answer for objects we can see through clearly.

questions.question_text: Frosted glass is an example of a:
questions.explanation_correct: Frosted glass allows some light to pass through but scatters it, so objects on the other side appear blurred and unclear. This makes it a translucent material.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Frosted glass is not transparent (you cannot see clearly through it) and not opaque (some light does pass through). It is not luminous (it does not produce light). It is translucent because it allows partial light through.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an opaque material?
questions.explanation_correct: A wooden door does not allow any light to pass through it. You cannot see anything through a wooden door. Materials that block all light are called opaque materials.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Clear glass and clean water are transparent — light passes through them completely. A thin plastic sheet may be transparent or translucent. A wooden door blocks all light completely, making it opaque.

questions.question_text: Materials that allow light to pass through them completely are called ___ materials.
questions.explanation_correct: Transparent materials allow all or most light to pass through them. We can see objects clearly through transparent materials. Examples include clear glass and air.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct term is 'transparent.' These materials allow light to pass through completely, unlike translucent (partial) or opaque (no light through).

questions.question_text: What are the three things needed to form a shadow?

options.text: A light source, a transparent object, and a screen
A light source, an opaque object, and a screen
A mirror, an opaque object, and a wall
Two light sources and a screen

questions.explanation_correct: To form a shadow, three things are needed: (1) a source of light, (2) an opaque object to block the light, and (3) a screen (surface) on which the shadow is formed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A transparent object would allow light through and not form a shadow. A mirror reflects light, it is not needed for shadow formation. Two light sources are not required. The correct combination is a light source, an opaque object, and a screen.

questions.question_text: A shadow is always black, regardless of the colour of the object.
questions.explanation_correct: Shadows are always dark (black) because they are formed in the region where light is blocked by an opaque object. Since no light reaches the shadow region, it appears dark regardless of what colour the object is.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. A shadow is formed where light cannot reach. Since there is no light in the shadow region, it always appears dark/black, no matter what the colour of the object that casts it.

questions.question_text: Why does a transparent object not form a dark shadow?

options.text: Because transparent objects are too small
Because transparent objects absorb all light
Because light passes through transparent objects
Because transparent objects are always colourless

questions.explanation_correct: Transparent objects allow light to pass through them. Since light is not blocked, there is no dark region on the other side. Therefore, a transparent object does not form a dark shadow.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The size or colour of the object is not the reason. Transparent objects do not absorb all light — they allow it to pass through. Because light passes through, no shadow is formed.

questions.question_text: The image formed in a plane mirror is:

options.text: Erect and of the same size
Inverted and of the same size

questions.explanation_correct: A plane mirror forms an image that is erect (upright), of the same size as the object, and at the same distance behind the mirror as the object is in front. The image is also laterally inverted (left-right reversed).
questions.explanation_incorrect: A plane mirror does not invert the image upside down, nor does it change the size. The image is erect (upright) and the same size as the object.

questions.question_text: What does 'laterally inverted' mean in the context of a plane mirror image?

options.text: The left side of the object appears as the right side in the image and vice versa
The image is bigger than the object

questions.explanation_correct: Lateral inversion means the left-right reversal of an image. In a plane mirror, the left side of the object appears as the right side of the image and the right side appears as the left side. For example, if you raise your right hand, your image appears to raise its left hand.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lateral inversion is not about the image being upside down, bigger, or blurred. It specifically refers to the left-right reversal — what is on the left of the object appears on the right in the image.

questions.question_text: A pinhole camera forms an image that is:

options.text: Inverted and may be smaller or larger

questions.explanation_correct: A pinhole camera forms an inverted (upside down) image. The size of the image depends on the distance between the pinhole and the screen — it can be smaller or larger than the object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A pinhole camera always forms an inverted image because light travels in straight lines through the tiny hole. The image is not erect. Its size depends on the distance of the screen from the pinhole.

questions.question_text: Which principle of light does a pinhole camera demonstrate?

options.text: Light travels in a straight line
Light can pass through all materials

questions.explanation_correct: A pinhole camera works on the principle that light travels in straight lines (rectilinear propagation of light). Light from the top of an object passes through the pinhole in a straight line and reaches the bottom of the screen, and vice versa, forming an inverted image.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A pinhole camera does not demonstrate bending of light, light passing through all materials, or reflection. It demonstrates that light travels in straight lines — this is why the image formed is inverted.

questions.question_text: During a power cut at night, you cannot see anything in a room. This is because:

options.text: Your eyes stop working during a power cut
There is no source of light in the room
Objects become transparent in the dark
The walls absorb all the objects

questions.explanation_correct: We see objects when light from a source falls on them and reflects into our eyes. During a power cut at night, there is no source of light in the room, so no light reflects off objects, and we cannot see them.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Our eyes do not stop working. Objects do not become transparent. Walls do not absorb objects. The reason is simply the absence of a light source — without light falling on objects and reflecting to our eyes, we cannot see.

questions.question_text: Sunglasses allow you to see through them but reduce the brightness of light. They are best classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: Sunglasses allow some light to pass through but block a portion of the light to reduce brightness. Since they let some (but not all) light through, they are best classified as translucent. You can see through them, but the view is somewhat dimmed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If they were fully transparent, they would not reduce brightness. If they were opaque, you could not see through them at all. They are not luminous since they do not emit light. Sunglasses are translucent as they allow partial light through.

questions.question_text: On a sunny day, Reema noticed that her shadow was shorter than her height at noon but longer in the evening. Why does this happen?

options.text: Reema's height changes during the day
The position of the Sun changes; when the Sun is overhead, shadows are shorter
The ground absorbs light differently at different times
Shadows are always the same length

questions.explanation_correct: The length of a shadow depends on the position of the light source. At noon, the Sun is almost directly overhead, so shadows are short. In the evening, the Sun is low near the horizon, and light falls at an angle, creating longer shadows.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Reema's height does not change during the day. The ground does not affect shadow length. Shadows are NOT always the same length. The changing position of the Sun causes the change in shadow length.

questions.question_text: A student holds a book between a torch and a white wall. What will be observed on the wall?

options.text: The wall will be fully bright
A shadow of the book will be formed on the wall

questions.explanation_correct: A book is an opaque object. When placed between a light source (torch) and a screen (wall), it blocks the light, forming a shadow of the book on the wall.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The wall will not be fully bright because the book blocks some light. The book will not glow since it is non-luminous. A shadow will definitely form because the book is opaque and blocks the path of light.

questions.question_text: When you write the word 'AMBULANCE' on the front of an ambulance, it is written in a mirror-reversed way. Why?

options.text: So that it reads correctly in the rear-view mirror of the vehicle ahead
Because the ambulance driver cannot read normal letters
Because paint spreads differently on metal

questions.explanation_correct: The word 'AMBULANCE' is written in reverse (mirror writing) so that when a driver of a vehicle ahead sees it in their rear-view mirror, the lateral inversion of the mirror makes the word appear correct and readable, alerting them to give way.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is not for artistic purposes, nor because the driver cannot read, nor because of paint behaviour. The reverse writing is specifically so that the word reads correctly when seen in a rear-view mirror due to lateral inversion.

questions.question_text:
Classify the following materials:
(i) Cardboard — (ii) Clear glass — (iii) Butter paper
The correct classification is:
questions.explanation_correct: Cardboard does not allow any light through (opaque). Clear glass allows all light through and you can see clearly (transparent). Butter paper allows some light but objects appear blurred (translucent).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The three materials have different light-transmitting properties. Cardboard blocks all light (opaque), clear glass transmits all light (transparent), and butter paper transmits some light (translucent).

questions.question_text: If you use a point source of light (like a small LED), the shadow formed will have:

options.text: A very light shadow with blurred edges
A dark shadow with sharp edges

questions.explanation_correct: A point source of light produces a shadow with sharp, well-defined edges because all the light comes from a single small point. There is a clear boundary between the shadow region and the illuminated region.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A point source does form a shadow (not 'no shadow'). The shadow is dark with sharp edges, not blurred or coloured. Blurred edges occur with extended (large) light sources, not point sources.

questions.question_text: If you stand 2 metres in front of a plane mirror, your image will appear to be 2 metres behind the mirror.
questions.explanation_correct: In a plane mirror, the image is formed at the same distance behind the mirror as the object is in front of it. So if you stand 2 metres in front, your image appears 2 metres behind the mirror.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. A plane mirror always forms the image at the same distance behind it as the object is in front. So 2 metres in front means the image is 2 metres behind the mirror.

questions.question_text: A firefly (jugnu) glows at night. It is a:
questions.explanation_correct: A firefly produces its own light through a chemical reaction in its body (bioluminescence). Since it emits its own light, it is a luminous object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A firefly is not non-luminous because it does produce its own light. It is not transparent or translucent — those terms describe whether light passes through a material. Since it emits light, it is luminous.

questions.question_text: In a pinhole camera, if the pinhole is made larger, what will happen to the image?

options.text: The image will become brighter but blurred

questions.explanation_correct: If the pinhole is made larger, more light enters, making the image brighter. However, light from different parts of the object overlaps on the screen, making the image blurred and less sharp.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A larger hole does not make the image sharper — it makes it blurred because light rays from different points overlap. An image is still formed, so 'no image' is wrong. The image does not become smaller. It becomes brighter but blurred.

questions.question_text: During a solar eclipse, the Moon's shadow falls on the Earth. In this case, the opaque object is:
questions.explanation_correct: During a solar eclipse, the Moon comes between the Sun and the Earth. The Moon acts as the opaque object that blocks the Sun's light, casting its shadow on the Earth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Sun is the light source. The Earth is the screen where the shadow falls. The stars are not involved. The Moon is the opaque object that blocks the Sun's light and casts a shadow on the Earth.

questions.question_text: A bathroom window uses frosted glass instead of clear glass. The reason is:

options.text: Frosted glass is stronger than clear glass
Frosted glass blocks all light completely
Frosted glass allows light in but does not allow a clear view (privacy)

questions.explanation_correct: Frosted glass is translucent — it allows light to enter the bathroom (keeping it bright) but does not allow a clear view from outside, providing privacy. This is why it is used in bathroom windows.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The main reason is not strength, cost, or blocking all light. Frosted glass is translucent, allowing light in while preventing clear visibility from outside, which provides privacy.

questions.question_text: If you hold the letter 'P' in front of a plane mirror, how will it appear in the mirror?
questions.explanation_correct: A plane mirror laterally inverts the image (left-right reversal). The letter 'P' when laterally inverted appears like 'q' — the vertical line is now on the right and the curve faces left.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Due to lateral inversion in a plane mirror, the left and right sides are swapped. The letter P, when reversed left-to-right, looks like a lowercase 'q'. It is not 'd' (which would be a vertical flip) or 'b'.

questions.question_text: Two shadows are formed when two light sources illuminate an opaque object from different directions. If one light source is turned off, what happens?

options.text: One shadow disappears and the other remains
The shadows merge into one large shadow

questions.explanation_correct: Each light source creates its own shadow on the opposite side of the object. When one light source is turned off, the shadow created by that source disappears. The shadow created by the remaining light source stays.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both shadows do not disappear because one light source is still on. They do not both become darker or merge. When one source is off, only its corresponding shadow disappears; the other shadow remains.

questions.question_text: Which of the following pairs correctly lists one luminous and one non-luminous object?
questions.explanation_correct: The Sun is luminous (produces its own light through nuclear reactions) and the Moon is non-luminous (reflects sunlight). This pair correctly identifies one luminous and one non-luminous object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Moon and stars: stars are luminous but the Moon is non-luminous — this does not list one of each in the right order. A torch that is off does not emit light, so it is not luminous at that moment. Mirror and glass are both non-luminous. Only 'Sun and Moon' correctly pairs a luminous and a non-luminous object.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Shadows are formed by opaque objects but not by transparent objects.
Reason: Transparent objects allow all light to pass through them.
Which of the following is correct?

options.text: Both assertion and reason are correct, and the reason explains the assertion
Both assertion and reason are correct, but the reason does not explain the assertion
The assertion is correct but the reason is incorrect
Both assertion and reason are incorrect

questions.explanation_correct: The assertion is correct — opaque objects form shadows because they block light, while transparent objects do not form shadows. The reason correctly explains this: transparent objects allow all light through, so there is no blocked region to create a shadow.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both statements are factually correct, and the reason directly explains the assertion. Because transparent objects allow all light through, no shadow is formed — this is exactly why only opaque objects form shadows.

questions.question_text: A student experiments with shadows by moving a torch closer to and farther from an object. She observes that as the torch moves closer to the object, the shadow on the wall becomes:
questions.explanation_correct: When the light source is brought closer to the opaque object, the shadow becomes larger because the light diverges more from a nearby source, causing a bigger blocked region on the screen.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Moving the light source closer does not make the shadow smaller or cause it to disappear. The shadow gets larger because light from a closer source spreads out more, casting a bigger shadow.

questions.question_text: Which of the following letters will look the same when seen in a plane mirror?
questions.explanation_correct: The letter 'A' is symmetrical about its vertical axis — the left and right halves are mirror images of each other. When laterally inverted by a plane mirror, it looks the same as the original letter.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Letters B, P, and J are not symmetrical about their vertical axis, so they look different when laterally inverted. The letter A has vertical symmetry, so its mirror image looks the same.

questions.question_text: In a pinhole camera, the image of a tall tree appears small on the screen. To make the image larger, you should:

options.text: Move the pinhole camera closer to the tree

questions.explanation_correct: Moving the pinhole camera closer to the tree means the tree subtends a larger angle at the pinhole. This makes the image formed on the screen larger. Alternatively, increasing the distance between the pinhole and the screen (using a longer box) also increases image size.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Making the pinhole bigger would blur the image, not enlarge it. Painting the screen does not change image size. A smaller box would make the image smaller. Moving closer to the tree makes the image larger.

questions.question_text: Stars are luminous objects, yet we cannot see them during the day. The reason is:

options.text: Stars stop shining during the day
The Sun's bright light makes the faint starlight invisible to our eyes
Stars move to the other side of the Earth during the day
Our eyes do not work properly during the day

questions.explanation_correct: Stars shine all the time, even during the day. However, the Sun's intense light scattered by the atmosphere is so bright that the faint light from distant stars cannot be seen by our eyes. At night, when the Sun sets, the sky is dark enough for starlight to be visible.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Stars do not stop shining during the day. Some stars are always above the horizon during the day. Our eyes work fine during the day. The real reason is that the Sun's brightness overwhelms the faint starlight.

questions.question_text: A ball is placed between two torches positioned on opposite sides. How many shadows will be formed?
questions.explanation_correct: Each light source (torch) creates its own shadow on the opposite side of the ball. With two torches on opposite sides, two shadows will be formed, one on each side of the ball.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Shadows are not cancelled by having two light sources. Each torch produces its own separate shadow on the side opposite to it. So two torches produce two shadows.

questions.question_text: A student places three different materials — clear glass, wax paper, and a metal sheet — in front of a torch one by one. Which observation is correct?

options.text: Clear glass: dark shadow, Wax paper: faint shadow, Metal sheet: no shadow
Clear glass: no shadow, Wax paper: faint shadow, Metal sheet: dark shadow

questions.explanation_correct: Clear glass is transparent (no shadow). Wax paper is translucent (partial/faint shadow because some light is blocked). Metal sheet is opaque (dark shadow because all light is blocked).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Different materials interact differently with light. Transparent materials (glass) form no shadow, translucent (wax paper) form faint shadows, and opaque (metal) form dark shadows.

questions.question_text: If you write the time '12:05' on a card and hold it in front of a mirror, what time will the mirror show?

options.text: The numbers will be reversed left to right

questions.explanation_correct: A plane mirror causes lateral inversion — the left and right sides are reversed. So the digits and their arrangement will appear reversed left to right. Each digit will also appear laterally inverted.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The mirror does not rearrange the digits into a different time — it laterally inverts the entire image. The numbers appear reversed from left to right, as if you were reading the card from behind.

questions.question_text: The colour of a shadow depends on the colour of the opaque object.
questions.explanation_correct: Shadows are always dark (black) regardless of the colour of the object. A shadow is simply a region where light is blocked. Since no light reaches the shadow region, it appears dark, not the colour of the object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is false. Shadows are always dark because they are regions where light does not reach. The colour of the object does not affect the colour of its shadow.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a luminous object?
questions.explanation_correct: A polished steel spoon does not produce its own light. It may reflect light and appear shiny, but it is a non-luminous object. The other options (tube light, burning matchstick, LED bulb) all produce their own light.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A glowing tube light, burning matchstick, and lit LED bulb all emit their own light (luminous). A polished spoon only reflects light — it does not produce any light of its own, making it non-luminous.

questions.question_text: Why is the image formed in a pinhole camera inverted?

options.text: Because the pinhole bends the light downward
Because light from the top of the object travels in a straight line through the pinhole and reaches the bottom of the screen, and vice versa
Because the screen is placed upside down
Because the camera box is too small

questions.explanation_correct: Light travels in straight lines. Light from the top of the object passes through the small pinhole and continues in a straight line to the bottom part of the screen. Similarly, light from the bottom goes to the top of the screen. This criss-crossing of light rays creates an inverted image.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pinhole does not bend light. The screen is not placed upside down. Box size is not the cause. The inversion occurs because light travels in straight lines — rays from the top go to the bottom and rays from the bottom go to the top of the screen.

questions.question_text: A student wants to classify materials as transparent, translucent, or opaque. Which experiment should she perform?

options.text: Weigh each material on a balance
Hold each material in front of a light source and observe how much light passes through
Measure the temperature of each material
Observe the colour of each material

questions.explanation_correct: The classification of transparent, translucent, and opaque is based on how much light passes through a material. By holding each material in front of a light source and checking visibility through it, she can classify them correctly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Weight, temperature, and colour are not related to transparency. The classification depends on light transmission, so the correct method is to observe how much light passes through each material.

questions.question_text: A plane mirror is placed on the floor facing upward. An object is placed above it. Where will the image appear?
questions.explanation_correct: A plane mirror forms an image at the same distance behind the mirror as the object is in front of it. Since the object is above the mirror, the image will appear to be below the mirror (inside the floor), at the same distance below as the object is above.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The image is always formed behind the reflecting surface of the mirror. Since the mirror is on the floor facing up, 'behind' means below the floor. The image appears at an equal distance below the mirror.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about shadows is INCORRECT?

options.text: Shadows are formed on the opposite side of the light source
Shadows give information about the shapes of objects
Shadows show the exact colour and details of the object
The size of a shadow depends on the distance of the light source from the object

questions.explanation_correct: Shadows do NOT show the colour or fine details of an object. A shadow is simply a dark region where light is blocked. It only shows the outline/shape of the object, not its colour, texture, or details.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Statements A, B, and D are all correct. Shadows form opposite to the light source, give information about shapes, and their size depends on the distance of the light source. Statement C is incorrect because shadows do not show colour or details.

questions.question_text:
Consider the following:
(i) Sun  (ii) Moon  (iii) Electric bulb (switched on)  (iv) Planet Mars
Which of these are luminous objects?
questions.explanation_correct: The Sun produces its own light (luminous). An electric bulb that is switched on emits light (luminous). The Moon and Planet Mars are both non-luminous — they only reflect sunlight and do not produce their own light.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Moon and Mars are non-luminous because they do not emit their own light — they only reflect sunlight. Only the Sun and a lit electric bulb produce their own light, making them luminous.

questions.question_text: The image formed in a plane mirror is ___ inverted.
questions.explanation_correct: The image in a plane mirror undergoes lateral inversion, meaning the left and right sides are reversed. This is called lateral inversion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct term is 'laterally.' In a plane mirror, the image is laterally inverted — the left-right sides are swapped. The image is NOT vertically inverted (upside down).

questions.question_text: If you look through a piece of coloured cellophane paper, you can see objects on the other side, but they appear coloured. This material is:
questions.explanation_correct: If you can see objects clearly through a material, it is transparent. Coloured cellophane paper allows light to pass through completely (though it filters certain colours), and objects are visible clearly, making it transparent.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If objects on the other side are clearly visible, the material is transparent. Opaque blocks all light. Translucent allows some light but objects appear blurred. Non-luminous is about light emission, not transmission. Cellophane is transparent.

questions.question_text: At what time of day would your shadow be the shortest when standing outdoors?
questions.explanation_correct: At noon, the Sun is almost directly overhead. When the light source is directly above, the shadow is at its shortest because the light rays fall almost vertically. In the morning and evening, the Sun is at a low angle, creating long shadows.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Shadows are longest when the Sun is near the horizon (morning and evening). At noon, the Sun is nearly overhead, making shadows the shortest. At midnight there is no sunlight for shadows.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is TRUE about the image formed by a pinhole camera?

options.text: The image is erect and the same size as the object
The image is inverted and its size depends on the distances involved
The image is always the same size as the object
The image is laterally inverted like a mirror image

questions.explanation_correct: A pinhole camera always forms an inverted image. The size of the image depends on the distance of the object from the pinhole and the distance of the screen from the pinhole. If the object is closer or the screen is farther, the image is larger.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The image is not erect — it is always inverted. It is not always the same size as the object. It is not laterally inverted like a mirror — it is fully inverted (upside down). Its size varies based on distances.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about plane mirrors is CORRECT?

options.text: The image is formed in front of the mirror
The image is smaller than the object
The image is virtual, erect, and of the same size as the object
The image can be captured on a screen

questions.explanation_correct: A plane mirror forms a virtual image (cannot be captured on a screen) that is erect (upright), the same size as the object, and at the same distance behind the mirror. It is also laterally inverted.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The image is formed behind the mirror (not in front). It is the same size (not smaller). It is virtual and cannot be captured on a screen. Option C correctly describes all the properties.

questions.question_text:
Match the following:
(i) Window glass – P. Opaque
(ii) Wooden plank – Q. Translucent
(iii) Ground glass – R. Transparent
The correct match is:
questions.explanation_correct: Window glass is transparent (R) — you can see through it clearly. A wooden plank is opaque (P) — no light passes through. Ground glass is translucent (Q) — light passes partially, objects appear blurred.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Window glass = transparent (R), wooden plank = opaque (P), ground glass = translucent (Q). The correct matching is (i)-R, (ii)-P, (iii)-Q.
